I suddenly feel like my 9 top tier conference publications in Machine Learning and optimizations, my grad research and thesis in Machine Learning, my work in Machine Learning are shit before a guy who‚Äôs got MooC certificates. Please tell me what those certificates are.

So here is the thing, when you apply for FAANG ML roles with those certificates, forget about Applied Scientists, which I work as, they won‚Äôt even consider those certificates for Machine Learning Engineer positions. Not trying to mock you, but no one gives shit about those certificates on LinkedIn. When I want to interview a candidate, I look at how many publications the candidate has, and what conferences did the candidate publish in. Even if you have one ICML publication, you‚Äôd have a shot at it.That so called ML by Stanford on Coursera, it‚Äôs not the total Machine Learning.I‚Äôd consider a person with one conference publication in ICML or CVPR over a person with 40 MooC certificates in ML for a job.After all, anyone can get those MooC certificates.My advice, do research, publish a paper, work on ML projects, then get experience. That would help if you can‚Äôt go to school again.PS: Before you say something, I went to Stanford.

Never a good idea to roll over a 401k to a new employer. 401k are almost shit plans in favor of brokerages.You should rollover it to a traditional ira account which will get you access to better funds. If you have an existing traditional ira then rollover to it. If not then work with fidelity to get one opened there since it would be easiest.
Rolling over to a traditional IRA subjects you to huge taxes if you attempt a backdoor Roth IRA contribution. For that reason alone keeping it in a 401k is a good idea.
If the amount is small then regardless every single dime should be converted to Roth. No penalty... just regular taxes.
roll it over to a Roth IRA and invest in stonks
Don't do this if you plan to do a Backdoor Roth. It makes things more complicated.
